communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: THE FRENCH PRESIDENCY.
div.p: The election to the Branch Preside og bay gode in favour of M. Pallières, the favourite candidate. He is the type of the modern French bourgeois and probably gained the victory over M. Doomer, his only serious rival, because he was considered a "safe" man. He was the ohorea candidate of the Ropablican groups, whilo M. Doomer was the candidate of the Opposition and the Nationalist Press. The.ver. The President does not count, politically speaking, ha a "strong" man; bat he is moderata and bound, and in his Presidential bands the policy which X. Loubet so strongly encouraged towards Great Britain and Italy will andargo no significant change. M, Daamer, on the other hand, is the
typical trong tin, Bolf-willed, self conTent and ambitious of popularity and power.

nge, however, at the present moment, bus la mora immediate need of a "safe". than of a Lattong man, and this consideration probably I decided the Voting in favour of M. Pallières. IM. Doomar represented an unknown quantity.

Battering the Chamber 43 Socialist, he aban. donned bio strong view to accept from a Radio Ministry the post of Governor-General of Indo-China, In this capacity be made no particular mark, bat by recommending a campaign in Yunnan, which could not have failed to involve Franos in various international complications, especially with Great Britain, he established for himself a reputation for rashness, and his return to Prance was greeted with a sigh of relief from the older and more prodent members of the Republican Party,
Since then he has ford ibig pics on all sides To This undeniably brilliant abilities. A good

speaker and a better talker, popular in Society, 1 he is a sort of Proñah Randolph Churchill, bat a Randolph Charobill whoso gradual drift instead of being from the Conservative to the Liberal side is from the Left to the Right That is where the danger Lay from the Rspablions point of view..

IM. Doumer's candidature for the Presidency of the Republic had been &p90088fal be would have been greatly indebted to the Right and to the Nationalist Left. He would have consequently had to repay his allies. Now the Constitutional prerogatives of a President of the French Republic. are extremely limited, and personal interference on his part in home Questions would be promptly regatta 1. It is mainly, if not only, in 00spection with foreiga questions that the. French President's influence can make itself directly felt. As Chief of the State be opmeye free goatly into contact With the Crowned Heads of Barope, and within I the mgagare of his diplomatic skill be muy do hazm or good. Should M. Doamor has been elected to the Presidency he would have beta constitutionally debarred from rewarding his Conservative and Nationalist friends in the Chamber and the Senate otherwise than by giving,80 far as his personal influence permitted' a different trend to the foreiga policy of Franco. M. Loubet's earnest and parristeat efforts to bring about a reconciliation with England and Italy were Dovor popular with the Conservatives and were the absolute negation of the Nationalist programma. It is true that the Dao P'Orléans has proo:aimed, in the little lithographed sheet which is now his only official organ, Correspondence Nationals at Les Nouvelles, that he is absolutely in fayjar of an

liance with Bogland, but nonetheless the party of the Right in the Proach Chamber is still greatly under the inflation of the Clerical and particularly the Roman Party, which is naturally hostile to the entente with Italy, and has no superabounding affection to borrow upon Protestant England. These are some of the considerations which have in laced the Union Répablicaine, which combines all be Ropublican Left with the exception of the Unified Socialists, to oppose the candidature of M. Doomar tooth and nail, and in view of the modace of the Moroccan Conference, which bangs over Rarope, the oleo ion of M. Fallières was the wiser choice.

div.head: Accession Honours.
div.p: The list of Accession Honours and promotions will be pabliebed in Monday's "Official Journal."

div.head: New Lady Dentist
div.p: Messrs. Mibotad Utodjian and George G. Razis, physicians, and Mme. Marie D. Glantz, dentist, have been authorised to practise in Egypt

div.head: Ismailia Canal
div.p: Owing to the difficulty of getting the altera. tions necessary to the lamailia Canal at Ismailia completed, navigation through the looks at Ismailis will not be open till the end of Japosty.

div.head: A. L. M. & D. S.
div.p: The date of the musical and dramatic enter. tainment to be given under the auspices of the Alexandris Literary, Musical and Dramatic Society has been postponed till Tuesday, the 30tb iust. .

div.head: Russian Consulate.
div.p: M. Chalkonoff, Russian Congal at Alexan. dria, visited the Governor this morning and introduced to his Excellency M. D'Absza the Duly-appointed Rassian Consul, who recently arrived here to take up his duties.

div.head: North Egypt Land Company, Ltd.
div.p: Application has been made to the London Stock Exchange Committee to appoint a special settling day in North Egypt Land Com. pany, Limited - 100,0 shares of £1 each fully paid, No8. 1 to 100.000.

div.head: S. P. O. A.
div.p: The branch of the Cairo Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which was formed in the bandar of Beoba, has bad the Boope of its efforts official.y enlarged so as to cover the whole of the Kaliouby Mondirieh.

div.head: Egyptian Estates.
div.p: The Egyptian Batates, Limited, has just purchased the property of Mr. Amabile Cumbo at Atleh. The estate is situated on the Mahmoudieh Canal and its area is about 2,200 feddans. The company purchased the property on favourable terms.

div.head: Ottoman Anniversary.
div.p: A local committee was formed recently of distinguished Cairo notables under the chair. Manship of Mohamed Arif Bey (ex member of the Legislative Council) to celebrate the anniversary of the establishment of Ottoman power in Cairo. The fete this year will be held on the 26th inst, at the Grand Continental Hotel.

div.head: Matrimony and Manslaughter.
div.p: A native of Gheziret Beba recently divorced his wife. This woman had been divorced by & previous husband a few years ago, by whom she bad had a girl. Her latest husband wanted to marry this girl after having obtained a divorce from her mother, but the family objected and a fight engraved three days ago wherein one of the relations was killed. Ao enquiry has been opened.

div.head: Railway Collision.
div.p: A collision took place at Abbassieh yesterday morning. It appears that owing to the mistake of & pointsman two training, one laden with sand ballast from the red bill and the other with forage from Abbassieh, ran into the central engine-house and there collided with an engine and two trucks. An engine was wrecked, several waggons were damaged, and an employé was killed. An enquiry is being held as to the cause of the accident.

div.head: At Medinet el Fayoum.
div.p: The old-world town of Medinet el Payoom is ·les: frequently visited by Egyptian travellers than its quaintness and interest deserve. It is a flourishing town, though much of it in architecture is as old as Roman times. The Mæris Hotel was built some little time ago and here a few days can be spent pleasantly and profitably. The Payoum region is noted for occasional good shooting. Mrs. J.P. Minis and her com. Danion and Mr. and Mrs. Stocks have been recently stopping at the hotel on the lake.

div.head: Union Artistique Française.
div.p: The members of the Union Artistique Française beld their annual general meeting last night and elected a new committee for the year 1906, as follows : President, M. Marcel Poilay Bey; vice-presidents, M. Salomon Wall hoff and M Joseph Levy ; commissaire de surveillance, M. A. C. Bortolotti ; directeur artisjoe, M. A. Roben ; directeur artistique adjoint, M. Julea Trapani; treasurer, M. Louie Pascal ; assistant treasurer, M. Victor Vivaldi societary, M. Alfred Scorman ; assistant secretary, M. Henri Lamon ; counsellor, MM Pernand Braun, Justin Paul, Robert O.C.More Constantin Prangoponlo, and Georges Roblié prompter, M. Aimé Paul; commissaire des fêtes, M. Herbert Thorn."

div.head: Trial of False Hallmarkers.
div.p: The preliminary entry into the case of the jewellers who were accused of forging hallmark op d adulterating gold has ended; and the Parquet at Alexandria decided yesterday to bring the accused to trial. Those men are Halil Ibrahim Zeitoun, Mohamed Ahmed El Gammal, Iskandar Nicola Hazzi, Yacou Odis, Georgia Odis, and Anees Hemdi. The first hearing of the case will take place on the 10:h proxo, at the Native Court. Tb Parquet asks the Court to sentence the scoored jewellers according to Article 17 of the Penal Code and Articles 40 and 30 of the esme ccde, are to be appended in 1 judgment against the last two persons name above.

div.head:
SPECIAL EMBASSY AT PORT SAID.
PRINCE ARTHUR AT THE SAVOY.
div.p: (PROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
Port Said, Wednesday. The King's Special Embassy to the Emperor -of Japan to convey to his Imperial Majesty the insignia of the Order of the Garter arrivals Port Said yesterday by the P. and 0. steam

bip Mongolia. The Embassy is headed by Prince Arthur of Coppaaght, and isolates also Admiral Sir & Seymour, General Sir Thomas Kelly Kenny, Lord Redesdale, Colonel A. Davidson, the King's Equerry, Captain Wyodaam, The Prince's Quarry, and Mr. Miles Lampson, of the Foreign Office, secretary of the Embassy.
Prince Arthur and the members of the Embassy dined at the Savoy Hotel here last night.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive came up to Abdeen to-day Erom Koobbeb and gave the audience to the MinIster, and to H. RH. Prince Charles Will. Liam of Sweden and the Duke of Argyll, the latter being accompanied by Lord Cromer. His Hips afterwards returned the Duke of Arıyll's visit at the Savoy Hotel.
The Khedive also granted an audience to M. Dimitroff and Miralai Matchett Bey.

div.head: THE GRAND CADI.
div.p: The Grand Cadi still insists that Mohamed Eff. Bl-Abassiri should be instated, and the Ministry of Justice still refuses to comply with his request. Consequently the administrative work of the Mehkemeh continues to be suspended.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: The Quarantine Board has decided to make the following annotation to bills of health delivered in Egyptian ports :-"Cattle plague has reappeared in the village of Kalamcha, Btsa district, Payoum mondirish. Very DeBary measures have been taken."
It has also been decided to suppress the Annotation concerning toot and mouth disease.

div.head: THE WAKFS.
div.p: A Commission has been formed with a view to make certain improvements in the organisation of this administration, and to consider the question of how best to allot the sam of L.E. 12,000 allotted in the recent Budget for the improvement of the condition of the personnel.

Abd el Halim Pacha Assem, Director: General of the Wakfu Administration, is president of the Commission. The other members are Adly Pacha Yaghen, Mahmood Pacha Pehmi, Said Paoba Shukri, and Abmed Bey Chafik.

div.head: THE CADRE.
div.p: At the last meeting of the Committee of Finance the question of the Cadre was disco 88 see the views of several heads of departments were laid before the meeting. Partner depression of the question was postponed probably till the retora of the Financial Adviser from Sudan. The Council of Ministers are not likely to have to sign the decree authorising the distribution of L.E. 120,000 in salaries till next March.

div.head: PROVINCIĀL KUTTABS.
div.p: Oar Damanhoar Correspondent writes : -

The new khattab at Delingat bas met with a very favourable reception in the locality. The idea of erecting a khattab was mooted at a recent meeting of the local notables and the scheme was enthusiastically taken ap. The Omdeh was most energetic and had the kattab built in a very short space of time at his own expense. He has undertaken to contribute L.B. 4 per mødsem to the cost of the scholastic staff of the kattab.

div.head: KENEH ASSIZES.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
Kepeh, Tuesday. The new Assize Court arrived at Keneb | last night. The Court is composed of Judge

J. 8. Willmore (president), and Judges Mohamed Bey said and Zowar Bey. They held a sitting this morning and beard two original cakes. Judge Willmore pronounced sentence of seven years' hard labour on Ja native of Loxor who had killed his brother by stabbing him with a knife. A quarrel tool place between the two brothers in a barber's shop, when the younger was offered by the elder owing to the youth wrangling with an old man in the shop. The younger waited
for his bro her and stabbed him at home the same night. The other 0190 was als 2 one of fratricide. The accused was sentenced to hard labour for life.The judges will say here for four day
until they have got through the cause list.

div.head: M. FALLIERES.
div.p: · NEW FRENCH PRESIDENT.
HIS LIFE AND CHARACTER.

M. Fellières, who has just been looted ident of the French Republic, was born 841, and is four years less than .M. Love He is, however, physically, a 1888 active ma Bat he loves the open air, and at his cb&tes

t Loopillon, in the Department of Lot ar Garonde, passes many hours of the de upon the estate, looking carefully to the prosperity of his vines and occupying biome with the hundred details of farm management Like this lato occupant of the Blysée, he n excellent shot. One might almost say that was the indispensable qualification of President, since a shooting party at Ran mouillet is one of the entertainments regular
offered to the guests of the nation. M. Loubo distinguishes himself amongst the peasants 1. Pallières is noted as a bilayer of the humbi abbit.

One might carry comparisons farther into the lives of the two men and say that, while 1. Loabet loves his pipe and the chimney corner, M. Pallières does not smoke at al The la's President has nọ ear for, mosio, an 188 & J baro'sian indifference to the Opéra mis successor to the Blysée bas, on the other band, a great pleasure in listening to the famous musical works of the world. He is a marly riser, like all good bourgeois, and i

qually averse from late boars at the other end of the day. Lot as say, also, that he is a great walker, notwithstanding a figure that i scarcely that of an athlete ; he is as attached to an umbrella as if it were a talisman. Tbi 8 a detail, perhaps, that it is not worth insist ng hapon, since it affords an uplacky compari non with Louis-Philippe.

Though M. Fallières, dating a short-live Premiership, was responsible for expelling tb Princes, he has, according to his enemies, "penchant" for "blue blood." However that may be, it is certain that bo gathers about hi cable persons of high degree, and his secretary is recruited amongst young men of excellent Family. It may, of course, be a more coincidence Dat it is sufficient to cause some extreme Ropable mang to bake their heads grimly when his name i mentioned. M. Pallière. Iss ap abundant speech us becomes a confirmed politician of over thirty Fears! standing indeed, the newly-elected President's public life is coeval with that of the Third Republic. When be prepares hi prations, as in reviewing the career of a deobas

d member of the Senate, one is struck with the aptness of his allusions and the choice of his language. In general, his impromptu are not zory remarkable. He is a man of sound reading principally amongst the classics, and with some Disdain for certain modern tendencies. He rarely takes pen in a band except to keep abreast of his personal and official correspondence. Aathorship 188 Dot tempted bim beyond a broobare on woon weighty matters of Parliamentary procedure. Sach is the manner of the mar rhom Fato has signalled oat to joy the high lace of the Republic.

div.head: RUSSIAN WARSHIPS AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Wednesday. The Russian battleship Aurora and the raiser Oleg arrived at Saez at 9 o'clock the wording from the Par Bost, and anchored in the Bay. The former was one of Admira fodjestvedsky's ships which went round the ape, whilst the latter passed through the anal onder Admiral Botrovosky. Both ships will enter the Canal at 6 a.m. to-morrow.

div.head: MARRIAGE OF MR. WENTWORTH-SHEILDS.
div.p: Mr. F. E. Wentworth-Sheilds, wh", ag ongi ber, will be engaged in the construction of the law Nile dam at Esneh, wav, at Ripon Cathedral last week, married to Miss Mary Boyd carpenter, third daughter of the Bishop lipon, in the presence of a large congregation

The bride, who was given away by her brother, Mr. W. B. Boyd-Carpenter, wore a ross of cream satin trimmed with miroi elvet and duchesse lace, the gift of her younger brother and sisters. She wore an eng nel pendant, presented by the bridegroom, breath of orange blossom, and a Limerick lac eil. Four bridesmaids were in attendance: Miss Margaret and Miss Hes'er Carpenter (i88 Malkin, and Miss Lucy Wine. They work ream solienne dresses trimmed with berthe I lace and oooox, add long sashes of ceria bbor, with cream drawn silk bata trimma with a chao of cerise ribbon and large whit ostrich feather. The bridegroom was attended by Mr. John Shaw as best man. The Bishop ipon officiated, assisted by the Dean of Ripon the Vicar of Leeds (Dr. Bickerstøth), and the esv. A. Guest. A reception was held after the ceremony at the Palace, among those present singing the Hon. Mrs. Fremantle, Viscount an 'iscountes: Mountgarret, Sir Reginald an rady Graham, Sir Henry and the Hon. Lady ogilvy. Mr. and Mrs. Wise, and Mr. and the Con. Mrs. Andrew Lawsop,
The honeymoon is being spent in Devonshire and Mr. and Mrs. Wentworth-Sheilds will learn for Egypt at the end of the month.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.

div.head:
LA TRAVIATA
AT CAIRO OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: SIGRA, BELLINCIONI'S PERFORMANCE
Signora Bellincioni has acquired a reputation, and not only at Alexandria, where reputations are easily come by, for her render
ing of the title role of Verdi's one sentimental journey in opera, and we expected moob o

her. Prankly the writer was disappointed Signora Bellincioni has a good voice ; aho acte well, her epgociation is clear, and her movements are graceful, but on Tuesday night at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, she failed to convince. Her singing wao, of course, good. for her admirable technique largely atoned
for the want of colour that marked her render-ing of some passages and the weakness of

her low notes. Her acting was • good conventional performance, but it failed to explain why Violetta enthralled Alfredo. Young man of Alfredoo type do not horrify their relatives by falling in love with highly proper members of the demi-monde, who do their best to play | at being ladies of the monde and usually and - by marrying widowed financiers, Alfredo in

real life soap dalisas or amuses the world by reading about with a high-kicking lass inordipately fond of jewels and champagne, and by falling into the dampe when Paotolas runs dry and his inamorata realises that someone else will supply her with diamonds. Now Violetta on Tuesday evening was lamentably decorous in the first ast, in which she is disonvered drinking champagne in a large quan. tities amid an assembly of rastagaovères and choraa girlo. Let her be sentimental, even pradieb, in Aot II., when she is genuinely in love with Alfredo, bat let her show a little more "abandon" in the opening soape when Alfredo is a stranger and she is sorronda. ed by boon companions. In real life Alfredo would have discreetly retired from the PROSEDOO of so staid and dignified a person and caused no further trouble on that score to Papa Germont | Perhaps the opera is to blame. Verdi cannot be sagary: to languorous death sobnog and the sentimentalism of all love he opposes a brutal directness, short and bloody death, and Beroe almost brutal passion. In Traviata be plays at being sentimental, and only in the drinking chorus, and perhaps in the air

Sempre libra di pensiero," is there any of that amazing vigour and swing that redeems even his cheapest melodies. Traviata was written for readers of La Dame aux Camelias, and now-well, it exists to give prima dandag a chance of displaying their high notes and their jewels

Or the rest of the paste Sig. Polese was the best. He looked dignified and apg well in a modern frock coat and black bowler-which is an achievement Pow operation artista CAR do both, Alfredo (Big. Bendinelli) was fair, bat one most hear and see him in another role before committing oneself. The orobestra was at its best.

div.head: THE TRADE OF EGYPT.
div.p: In our roview yesterday of the just-listed Customs returns for December, we dealt mainly with the import trade of the year, as shown by those ratarna. It is, however, interesting to make a comparison also of the returns for that month with those for the same month in 1904. The importa for last month, therefore, amounted in value to LR. 2,873,822, as against LE 2,418,750 in December, 1904, which is a decrease of LR. 45,428_not so very much when we remember the exceptional conditions of 1904 to which were referred to yesterday. While there was a decrease in the imports of merchandise of L.B 62,894, there was an increase in the tobacco imports of L B 6 966

Coming to exports, we find that under that heading there was an increase of L. E. 71,892 for December, and a decrease of nearly a million (ie, L. R. 450,755) for the twelve month. This was more than accounted for by the drop in the value of the cotton exported, which amounted to no loss than L R. 896,976, representing a very serious domination in the price of the articolo, as whereas in 1904 only 5,912,958 cantars were exported, last year the exports totalled 6 527,085 cantars. The total value of the exports in 1905 amounted to L.B. 20,860,285.

div.head: THE ALEXANDRIA RIOT.
div.p: The Native Court of Appeal was to have board yesterday the appeal of the natives who were a few weeks ago condemned by the Court of 1st Instance for participating in the rioting on the 10th December last at Alex: andria. The hearing was adjourned for a week in compliance with the request of counsel for the appellants

div.p: By kind permission of Liedt-Colonel R. C. 0. Cox, commanding, and officers, and Batt. Royal Indiskilling Fusiliers, the band will perform the following selection of mosio on the terrace, National Hotel, tomorrow (Friday) afternoon from 4 to 6:

Maroh El Capitan-Sousa. Overture-Haydée-Auber. Landler-Grossmutterohen-Lange. Selection-Adrienne Louvre-Cilia. Valse-Ensueno Soduotor-Rogas. Song--The Promise of Lifo-Cowen. Selection-A Runaway Girl-Caryll. Galop-Eisenbahn-Arndt Regimental March. - Kbodívial Anthem.

div.head:
SPORT AND PLAY.
FOOTBALL
SAINT ANDREW . VICTORIA COLLEGE
div.p: The Victoria College F. C. and St. Andrew P. O. played off their rotor fixture on the College ground on Saturday last. The home team started the game and were soon in Dear proximity to Wobb. Unsettled play by the visiting backs let the ground forwards in, and this resulted in the college scoring within two minutes of the start, the ball coming off the post at an angle which gave Wobb no chance to save. This parlorMANDA was nearly repeated immediately after the kick off, bat Hopkide affected a clearance. Midfield play followed for a time, the game opening oat well and both sides striving hard to get within shooting range. Buth baok divisions were well tested. Mustard was doing good work for his sido, and it was seldom that the Saints could get in apon Baba, Hopkins and Keill had now got quite settled and little passed them. Shortly before the call of half-time the college were rather lucky in getting a second goal, and the teams turned round with the score : College 2 ; St. Audrow 0.

The oorlede pressed at the start of the second half but the shooting of the forwards lost some good opportunities. The Saintal soon found their feet, and Sabs was toasted on several occasions, bat cleared cleverly. MR. STOUTS XI. v. BOULAC. On Friday, 19th inst., a football matola was played at the Khedivial Sporting Club, Cairo, between Mr. Stoat's XI. and the Railway Institute, in the presence of a good number of enthusiastic onlookers. The game was very fast at first, but the pace slowed down daring the remainder of the game. During the first half, play was of a very even character, and both teams strive hard for supremacy. The home team were first to spore, bat the Instituto 800n equalized. There was no further scoring, and 80 a well-contested game ended in a draw,

div.head: OBITUARY,
div.p: E BARON VON RICHTHOFEN.

Baron von Richthofen's death, which is Announced to-day, will be regretted in Egypt. I made many friends while representing Germany on the Public Debt Commission at Cairo from 1885 to 1896. The late Baron was born at Jassy in 1847 and had held the post | of Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs at Berlin since 1890. He entered the German Poraign Office in 1878. after having been in the Imperial Civil Service in Alsace-Lorraine. Afte: leaving Egypt in 1896 he became Director of the German Colonial Department. The Iste Baron was the onolo of Mra. Demosthenes Benedacci Bey, of Alexandria,

M. Fallières has been elected President of the Republic. He obtained 419 votee, his oppo. Dent M. Doomer obtaining 371. Reuter)
VERSAILLES, January 17. M. Pallières has been elected President of the Republic by 419 votes against 871 gizon to M. Doamer.

(Lavar VERSAILLES, Hungary 17. Vice-President Dabost and M. Roavier 10tified his election to M. Pallières, who replied expressing his gratitude and stating that he would scrupulously observe the Constitution. and that he would be inspired by courage. disinterestedness, and patriotism of MY. Labor.
On his return to Paris M. Pallières paid a cordial visit to M. Loubet.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MUNICIPALITY
div.p: MIXED MARRIAGES.

M. Seymour de Ricci, who has been visiting Egypt upon behalf of the l'rench Académie collecting Greek and Latin inscriptions, in a preliminary report on his acquisitions, ba abolished an important Greek papyrus relating to the city of Antinoopolis (Anticon) containing record of a meeting of the local Municipality his city founded by the Emperor Hadrian n memory of his favourite it appears,possessed certain special civic privileges. This report f & 8938ion of its officers is dated the 9th year 1 Antoninus Pius (A.D. 161), 21st day of the month Athyr. The subject for discussion at the meeting was a decree that had been tagged by the Egyptian Governor, Valerin Procalur, ou November 17, A.D. 145. H.

as already known as a prefect of Egypt, both from inscriptions and papyri, whose years office were 1157 A.D. The decree which, another Egypto Roman document referring to my way of legal record to such edicts, is on for unotelly not given in full, not merely noted by crossing the preliminary sentences. Doubt B88 the scribe of the council considered it to be familiar to all readers of the record of the proceedings, or at all events that it was asily referred to by them in the archives.
It would appear that Proculus' does controverted the right of citizens of Antinoopolis

contract mixed marriages with the native Egyptians that would be legal unions in Romar aw. In short, the controversy concerning l the validity of mixed marriage amongst the very heterogeneous population of the new Antinolis.

The fresh information provided by the papy as is contained in the splash of the Council's president who said "The right of mixed marriages with the Egyptian: Lag b3en bestowed upon 08 as a privilege by the divine

Adrian, this is a right which the people of Naucratis did not po 18893, whose laws aro ir ogae in our city." Prom this appears. that when founding the city, Hadrian granted its citizens the favour of being under the special laws of Nagoratis, which town, like Alexandria, Ptolemnis, and perhaps Horm molig Magna, is a Greek city.

The Greek status of these two had been raised from an inscription upon a statue to Verona, also papyri and ineceiptions, especially from Ptolemais and Antinoopolis, show that their populations were divided into> tribe of domog upon the Crook civic system. The address of the President also indicates the addition to enjoying Naucratitve privileges antinopolite citizens possessedd the right of mixed marriages.

div.head: CARDS AND CLEVERNESS.
div.p: Mr. Basil Tozer discusses the question ``Does aptitude for card-playing de rota general intelligence !" in the "Monthly Review." H wrote to a number of people on the subject
od received a number of interesting replies Among them are the answers of two gentlemen who were members of the Parliament dissol
d lately. Mr. Tozur does not give their names, as they did not desire them to b publisher, but says that they are so placed a o be in a position to speak with authority,
They are of opinion that, though an aptitude For card playing, and more especially for bridge playing, betokens intelligence in the playe: Pet, as the one pats it:

"Intelligence for playing cards is a brano of intelligence peculiarly its own, and my experience is that clever 989 at cards, chege end at figuras go generally hand in hand. personally am scopainted with quite a number of men who, though good at those three things are of very ordinary intelligence at all else, an singularly deficient in any sort of aptitude fc musio, literature, or painting." +
His friend also appears to have notice · lack of talent for music among men and women who are exceptionally brilliant card layers:

"It has always struck me (he says that the brain of the very skillful card-players can only be described as a 'msche miral' brain.... Also I have nover, the best of my recollection, met & very talented magician--by which I mean mor especially an instrumentalist, whose brain i

above all else volatile, whose tempersinent i mercurial and almost always emotional, and whose sense of humour is generally very cute-who was able to concentrate his atter ion upon a gang of cards for any length of time."

div.head: IN THE COUNTRY OF JESUS.
div.p: This is a translation of Matilde Serao '' Nel Paese di Gesù," which has obtained great popularity in Italy. It is a series impressions of a trip to the Holy Land by on of the most brilliant of modern Italian writer For the large number of tourists now in Egypt
who are contemplating a visit to Palestin before returning home, this book will be convenient adjunct to the guide-book. Th
translation reads easily and the illustrations are excellent.
In the Country of Jesus. Translated from the Italian atbildi Served by Richard Davos. Published by Willia Heidemann, London, 1995

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: 1 Lord Grenfell has been granted an extension of one year in the command of the troops in Ireland. The extension is to date from the 9th May next.

Lieutenant P. H. Hadow, Army Service Corps, Cork, has been placed under orders for service in Egypt, and has been directed to embark for Alexandria about the 10th prox. Lieutenant Had received his commission directly four years ago.
There is a feeling that the arrest of a num. the number of non-commissioned officers in connection with South African scandals is only the beginning. ving of the matter.

The new short rifle, and the bandolier for carrying the "charger packed" bali ammunition, are to be served out to the Brigade of Guards, and the battalions composing the First, Se ond, Third, Fourth, Pifth, and Sixth Infantry Brigades

The "Morning Post" understands that certain technical dishoulties have delayed for some months the iigne of the new short rifle to the infantry, the chief of these difficulties being the adaptation of the riflo for use by mounted infantry. These difficulties, however, in the opinion of the Army Coupoil, have now been overcome, and orders have been given for th3 immediate rearmament of the lofantry Batta. lions belonging to the Aldershot Army Corps. As regards mounted infantry, the orox has boon the question of the carriage of the rifle when the soldier is in the saddle. The cavalry retain their old system of carrying their firearm in a "bucket," almost identical with the carbide "bucket", which holds the rifle in its place without further support. Bat a rifle so placed rond 3r8 mounting and dismounting somewhat difficult for an inexperienced horseman and, moreover, the time taking it from the 'bucket' ' would somewhat delay the mounted infantryman coming into action. It has been necessary, therefore, to keep for the mounted infantry, the open Carrington ``booket," with which a short riff places the rifle somewhat too low to be comfortably gripped, and supported by the rider's right hand. To remedy this defect it has been decided to adjust the lower swing swivel, 80 as to enable the soldier, when riding, th, mora easily to pass his forearm through tha sling, and thas to keep his rifle in its place. Whether the rearmament of the First Army Corps with the abort rifle will be followed by the manufacture of immediate supplies for issue to the rest of the Rozalar Army and Auxiliary Forces is a matter which, there is reason to believe, is still under consideration.

There is no foundation for the statement freely made that a Japanese squadron was to come to British waters in the coming sommer in order to cooperate with the British aquadrong in the extensive made ivros which are in contemplation. The roar, no doubt originated from the fact that the manæ ivros will be carried out on the imaginary amalgama
tion of the British and Japanese fleets against | A combined Continental naval force.

div.head: THE OLYMPIC GAMES.
div.p: The American Athletic Committee has decided to send a team of sixty athletes to compete in all the events at the Olympic games at Athens.

The gamos, which include flat, hardlo, and walking race, jamping, throwing the discus and stone, putting the weight, cycle races weightlifting, wrestling, gymnastics, lawn ten bis, associa:ion football, fencing (foils, epée and sabres), swimming, diving, rowing, and shooting, commence on April 22, and will conclude on May 2 next. The athletic events will in all probability take place on April 48 89, and 30.

Subject to the acceptance of the English Amatear Athletic Asociation, the Central Committee in Athens has voted 5,000 franca (£208) towards the expenses of the British team. The matter will be considered by the General Committee of the A. A. A. at their next meeting. A hope is being expressed in English atletico circles that the ruling body will select the British representatives after public trials, as will be done in Amèrica and other countries.

In deference to the wishes of the British Executive Committee, a five-mile running race has been added to the programme, in which A. R. Charcbill, the Light Blue runner, ie expected to take part, others who have signified their intention of competing in the various events being K. Corowallis, R. W. Simers Smith, J. H. L. Yorke, S. H. Carnelly, of Oxford University ; S. Abrahams (Cambridge University), J. W. Morton, the 100 yarda amateur champion ; L. F. Tremor (London | A. C.), L. J. de B. Reed (South London H.). und H. E Hawtrey (Thames H. and H.). Wyndham Halswell, the Buglish and Scottie 440 yards champion, is also expected to make the trip.

His prayer for vic ory was nearly answered, but the referee, on points, called the bont a Araw. 0. leaving the club Allen declared that
evangelist or no evangelist wa must have a little ready money."

div.head: Egyptian Salt & Soda Company, Limited.
div.p: NOTICE. It has come to the notice of the Company that retailers of salt are selling to the pablo at a higher rate than 2 mm the kilo, the price fixed by the Government.
Every retailer before he is able to take coaTBO orground ealt from the Company agrees to retail the same to the public at 2 m/m the kilo.

The Company does not wish to interfere with legitimate retail trade, but unless retailers keep to their engagements, the Company will issue the salt directly from its shonabo to any person applying for it, at the fixed rate, 2 m/m the kilo.

div.head: MODERN EGYPT.
div.p: AN AMERICAN'S IMPRESSIONS
INTERESTING EXTRACTS.

- - An American journalist, Mr. William Eleroy Cartis,, has lately been paying a visit to Egypt on his way to the Far East and has jottel down his impressions of this country in a highly interesting fashion. Some of his observations are very just, as the following passage will show. We commend it to the notice of that class of tourist who complains of the dearness of hotels in Egypt :- . Egyptian Hotels

I do not understand how they can afford to entertain people at the prices they charge, because they are closed for eight months in the year, and have to depend upon four months' business for their profit, and are compelled to bring nearly all their supplies from abroad. They get their beef from America, their chickens from France, their vegetables from Italy, their hotter from Switzerland and Denmark, and their groceries from London. Several of the hotels have their own gardens and dairies which supply ordinary vegetables, milk and cream and you can get gepnine cream for your coffee at Shepheard's Hotel - the only place I know of between Paris and San Francisco. Pat Sheedy In Calro.
of that erstwhile familiar figure of Cairo in the season, Pat Sheedy, he remarks :

Oar eminent fellow.citizen, Patrick Sheedy, E:q. was engaged in business at Cairo for Boveral 8008009, and had compton, gambling rooms in the rear of Shepbeard's Hotel, which were popular and wall patronized by a large portion of the native as well as the foreigo population, bat several scandals among the officers of the British garrison having reached the ears of Lord Cromer, the police raided the place, confiscated Mr. Sheedy's professional parapbernal & and closed bim out. The chief of police took the trouble to adire: a letter to the United States Consul general requesting that Me. Sheedy -should be expelled from tba country, and was doubtless enterprise to learn that such a proceeding was impossible Among Americans. It is the popular opinion that Mr. Sheedy ran a "square game," and he himself declares that he never had the slightest difficulty with the Pachas or the Beys, or the Greeks, or the Jewe, or the tourists, bat every British officer who dropped a shilling quesled." Chicago's Influence on Cairo
The deplorable charges that have been brought against the Chicago Exhibition of having demoralised the Egyptian girls who went out there, are that dealt with :

It is painful 'to hear Egyptians say that their innocent dancing girls, or ghawazi, 28 they call them, the shameless creatures who stand on platforms in cales and other places of amplement, and wriggle their abdomens before a large audience of men, were demoralized by their association with Americans who visited the Midway during the world's fair. Patriotic Egyptians 8880re one with a serious face, and I haven't the slightest doubt of their sincerity, that the so-called dancers who went to Chioago brought back bad habits and immodest customs which have been imi. rated by those who stayed in at home until the "danse da ventre" is no longer respectable, and positively immoral. Foreigners who are not so fortunate as to have witnessed their behaviour before the Chicago epoch are, of course, helpless to disprove this awful calumny, but the enormous native population which crowds into the local cafés and theatres every night, and yells with enthusiasm at young women who are hired to wriggle their stomachs, is an evidence that the performance has not lost its popularity. We all realize that Chicago is tough, very tough, but when the city is accused of damaging the morals or the manners of the ladies attached to the streets of the Cairo show, the charge is actionable.

div.head: THE ARABIAN NIGHTS.
div.p: A study of the "Arabian Nights' ' has just appeared from the pen of Carra de Vaux. It is some proof of the blindness of critics--at any rate in the eighteenth century--that on their first appearance in Barope hardly any literary man thought much of them, and Voltaire, with his usual scepticism, opposed that their translator, Galland, had freely padded them with the efforts of his own imagination. That this was a mistake M. Carra de Vanx shows clearly enough; for the original text of "Aladdin," long the most suspect of the Tales, was discovered some time ago by Zatenborg, and as lately as 1901 M. Chauvin found that of "Ali Baba." On the other hand, the general public, wiser in this respect than their teachers, took to the "Arabian Nights' ' at once, and they have remained the favorites of the nursery ever since. M. Carta de Vaux attributes this to the marvels of magic which are to be found in all of them and which appeal particularly to the wonder-greedy minds of children ; while to their elders the love interest spread through them is almost equally dear. It is, indeed, extraordinary how constant in them is the idea of love-not the calculating Bod egoistic passion of frigid Northernera, but the electric shock of the Oriental, who is ready at the flash of a pair of dark eyes over & yash. mak, to sacrifice his lite or future to his charmer for the time being. For the tert, M. Carta de Vhox tells us that tho Tales were certainly first collected in Persia, that the mention of historical personages in thim in free from arachronisins, and that their dat is pretty well fixed as being earlier than the fifteenth century by the fact that they alleda neither to coffee nor to tobacco.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The improvement we foreshadowed last week in the monetary situation has taken place, and any fears of high rate for money seem to have disappeared. The effect of the election will be to retain some of the money in the provinces longer than is usual at this time of the year, but it is coming back and is likely to produce greater ease towards the end of the inov th Any question of a rise in the Bank rate has paired for the present.

In addition to this there is a gradual hat steady clearing of the political horizon. The German people and all the foreign diplomats are endeavouring to reassure the world on the subject of the Morocco conference. The illno88 of Baron von Richthofen, German Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, as a result of the abxiety the matter bag caused him, is evidence that the German diplomats have placed them. selves in an unsatisfactory position is the consequence of the impetuousness of the Kaiser's mood. Moreɔver, the £11,000,000 loan which Rnesia has been able to contract with French bankers, and the improved condition of the country itself, appears to have removed, at any rate for the present, any possibility of a financial crash in that quarter. · These two menaces being out of the way, the rest of the factors in the political situation are entirely on the side of expansion of trade and a rise in prices, and we should not be surprised to see the end of the month show very activo markets on all sides.
Speculation in Egypt.

Lo rogard to affairs Ezyptian, the warning which was given by the Financial Adviser' ag to over-speculation in that country, and which W28 daly copied into the newspapers bore, does not seem to have had any disturbing effect upoa Egyptian securities. The fact that the Government of Bayport, presumably with the concurrence of the Financial Adviser, are laying out millions of money non profitable works, is the best commentary upon pessimistic views as regards the country. The projects taken in hand by the Government are no doubt perfectly sound, and will be very romanerative, but they are not, after all, any less relative not more safe than the purchase of land, which in a prosperous country is seldom anything but remunerative.

The isgae if £159000 five per cent. Debentures hy the Bzyptian Estates Company, made this morning, will be welcomed by investors, A8, owing to good management, this company is considered one of the best. As we have previously stated, we hope to 809 more issues of Egyptian concerns on this safe buis of well-secured deben: tares. It is not only the most satisfactory manner in which the English investor can pat out his money in other countries, but ia beat also for Egyptian companies themselves, for they can thog obtain a large part of their lands at a reasonable rate of interest. The Egyptian Estates Company are obtaining 7% in Egypt on mortgage 88corities; this there is an immediate profit to them of 2%. At the same time, the investor here is glad of a safe security, even at 5% interest. Providing the companies issuing debentures are respectable and well. managed, there is practically no limit to the obtaining of money at this rate to help legitimate enterprises. This first i8800 of Debentures of the Egyptian Estates was taken up immediately by the best financial firms in London.
There has been little movement in this section since our last, nor is there likely to be any until the election is over. Consola are a little higher at 89 11/16 for the account.

A steady tone continues to prevail in the market for Russians, and at one time the Ponre were up to 85. They have declined, however, to 84 1. The difficulties which have beset Roesia for so long seem to be passing, and the increased confidence shown by the Paris bankors in granting the new loan is bound to be reflected in the price of the stocks here. Japanese bonds have been in demand at slightly higher prices.

There has been little doing in home railways, and there is no restore to record. This is another market which, as wa bave previously predicted, is likely to experience a large influx of business in the near future, all the distribution of dividend is expected to commence next week, and these are nearly all of a highly satisfactory character.

American rails have been a strong market, and a feature has been the demand for Denvers, which have risen to 41 Canadian Pacifice are being favoured on the publication of the very gratifying increase of 243,000 dollars in the traffics for the first week of the new year. The price of those stocks to night is 1808

There is not much to report regarding the Egyptian market during the past week. National Bank of Egypt have come back to 25 1-1, and Agricultural Banks to 9 - 4. the now igane of the latter being doll at about 9. Daira Sanieh Ordinary have changed hands at 17. bas close at 17 . The Deferred are steady at 102-6. Delta Preference bearer have been bought np to 12, bat on the declaration of the dividend yesterday at the rate of only 4 % the price fell away rapidly to 11 g seller, at which prica they close. The poor dividend is due to heavy working expenses. There has been some enquiry for Ezyp:ian Eitatus, which have been ap to 1, H1, bat leave off X-.

The Corporation of Western Egypt remains very firm at g-ti premium. Although there has been a fair amount of selling, the market Boom 8 to absorb any number of shares, and this is a good sign. Union Foncière closes at premium, and Abyssinian Banks, after being 1 premium, leave off - premium. Delta Land, Salt and Soda, and Egyptian Markets, are very pominal at 21, 1). and 1 5/16 respectively. Daira Sugar is a little better at 47. Mining

The satisfactory returns of the Rand gold output for 1903—the payout for December being of the value of £1,833,295, and that for the whole year £ 0,800,000—bave once more re-established this as the premier mining market of the world, and South African shares are being bought in steadily at higher prices.

The Egyptian section has been almost one mentioned, with the exception of Bzyptian Mines, which have jumped to 10/.. Nile Valleys are a trifle higher to-night at 7/6, 8/ after being fat all the work. Um Rus are 1/16 lower at $

div.head: THE COTTON MARKÉT.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT.

Liverpool, January 11. There has been a fair business in Egyptians this week. Quotations are uncharged, except for Fine Brown, which is to per lb lower. Flat Area have been moderately active, and the following are the latest value3 : - Jany. 7.61 Mob. 7.61 May 7.60 July 7.59 Poby. 7.61 Apk. 7.60 Jano 7.60 Ang. 7:59. • AMERICAN PICTURES - The Market this week has been fairly active, but very unsettled, flạctuations have been frequent and sharp, and the decline at times has amounted to 20 @ 22 points below last Thursday's closing rates. To-day there has been a sharp recovery and closing values are only 11 @ '2 points down on the week. The principal feature has been the heavy liquidation of "Ball" interests from New York, New Orleans, and the Con. tinent, no doubt influenced by the fact that the National Ginners Report acknowledged an error of 400,000 bales in their previous estimates. The Census Bureau's estimate of 9,700,000 was about the figure expected, and seems to indicate a crop of at least 10 millions. At over sixpence per lb. we are not sangaine for the article, 'in spite of very excellent trade conditions, because it seems to as that there will be ample supplies and present prices are high enough to stimulate heavy planting.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions axl rose by our correspondent, but wo wish, in a spirit of fair play to alto permit - within obtain nomeri Malta - true disarion. NATIVE OFFICIAL INSOLENCE.
A GREEK COMPLAINT.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,-The Greek community of Tala (Menoufieb) beg to expose in your esteemed paper the most unreasonable conduct of the mouwen police of the markaz Tala, Ibrahim Bff. Mahmood. The following sad accident happened in our village. Some days ago a poor ill Greek was found in a village near ours and was sent by the omdeh of that village to the markaz. No sooner did the unfortunate fellow arrive at the markaz than he died. The only thing he had a bad time to say was that he had had nothing to eat for the three last days of his sad life. Here begins the most unqualified conduct of the moon police, Ibrahim Bf. Mahmoud. This gentleman, little thinking of the consequence 98 that his sayings might have, soon after the death of the poor Greek mentioned, went op to a Greek gentleman living in our village and without any previous cause whatever announced the death to bim in the following manner : "A Christian dog died in the markaz'' (ouabad kelp noorani mat fol markaz). We are absolutely certain that every reasonable person-of whatever nationality or religion may be hesitatingly acknowledge that the above disgraceful words of the mowen constitute the most abhorrent profanation as regards the dead, that is supposed to be onder international respect. In the afternoon of the same day the same moon met another Greek collecting money for the bargain of the unfortunate dead, and asked him in pablo the following very impertinent question: "Have you collected money from the damned Christians 1" (lamet felous men el malažo el pasara). This was not his last inhalt. In the evening of the same day the same mouwen sitting at a café declared publicly in the presence of many native notables as well as some Greeks, that "all the Greeks are thieves' ' (el arwam koalonhonm haramis). That was not all either. Oor moawon was not satisfied yet of all he had insulted. After repeating in all the cafés and other pablo places that every Greek is a thiet, next day when the priest came for the burial of the deceased, he vomited his last insult to the dead in the presence of the priest and several Greeka, saying: "Here is your gift, Get it away from here." It is to be noticed that the dead was thrown in the place of a missing horse, inside the stables. As & natural consequence all the natives comment apontheidsolts of their mouwen, accompanying their remarks with very insulting comments of their own.

All the Greeks living in Tala, although in extreme excitement and indignation, have all the time shown an admirable self-control. Although their most sacred, their national teelings were born in the most foal, most sacrilegious way, thoy contented themselves with referring to their Vice-Consul at Tantah in a common petition. It is very congoling for the inolted that their Vice Consul, Mr. Andrew Vassiliou, exhibited a very energetic activity in this case. He went personally to the Moudir of Menu Fish to protest against the annalivia behaviour of the moaven and obtained from him forwally the promise that an enquiry will be opened on the subject and if the guiltiness of the moswan be proved that he will be punished accordingly. As there are 29 attendant circumstances whatever we are strongly in hope that full justice will be rendered. The Greek community of Tala (Menoofiah).
div.note: [Since the above was received we learn that the Ministry of the Interior has sent an inspector to Tals, who has opened an enquiry, and bas found that there were grounds for com. plaint as to the conduct of the official referred to.-Bd. E. G.

div.head: LA BOURSE DU CAIRE
div.p: Nous extrayons d'un article de la Bours Egyptienas un pasage qui complète l'expo de la question que nous avons publié hier :
Disons, ici, deux mots au sojet des de projets immobiliers qui se troavaient en pr sėdoe.

Le projet do transfert de la Bourse a Hawmam rencontrait, en premier lieu, l'host lité de la Corporation parce que ce projeto prévoyait qu'une simple prise à bail de l'im meuble. La Corporation dit avec raison quel construction de la nouvelle Bourse dans a endroit quelconque y crée un centre et door par conséquent, une plus value immédiate considérable aux terrains eu vironnants et a local dans lequel elle se tronve. Or, il eéquitable que la Société de la Bourse bénéfici sa tant que possible de cette base qui lui es entièrement due.

En plaçant la Bourse sur un terrain lo appartenant, la Société tirerait on revenu tre élevé du chef des locations de bureanx, cate restaurant, etc. que comporterait l'immeuble qu'elle pourrait construire à 88 guise. Er 8'installant comme simple locataire dans un immouble appartenant à d'autres, ce sont ce aatres goi bénéficioraient presque exclusive mont de la plae value en résultant.
Voici maintenant comment le Progrès, ré pondant à la Boarse, envisage la question :

Bien qu'il soit le promoteur de la combinaison relative à la Bourse, M. R. Suarog n'a jamais agi en son propre nom, mais tonjours comme représentant de tous les Banquiers. La solidarité entre lui et les autres membres de la haute finance a été d'ailleurs proclamée par la publicité donnée au procès-verbal de la réapion tende par les Banquiers, le 13 janvier, dans le local da Crédit Poocier. Se peut-il que ce document ait échappé à l'attention de notre confrère ?

L'hypothèse est inadmissible, et nous croyons plutôt qu'il imita l'autruche : il forme ley yaux pour ne pas le voir. Mais qu'il le veuille ou non, le conflit existe entre la haute finance réunio et les Agents de change divisés. Ooi, divisés ; car malgré la dialectique des moneura, malgré la pression exercée par eux sur leurs collègues, ceox-ci sont loin d'approaver à l'o. nanimité la raptare avec les Bseqoiers, et la Corheille offre en oo moment le spectacle d'ane petite cour da roi Pétaad...

La corporation des Agents de change n'a qa'un an d'existence et elle possède déjà aujourd'hui un capital social de douze mille livres. D'où lui vient ce capital 1 Le taux officiel d'admission des valeurs à la coto eat de £ 50 poar un capital inférieor à £ 4000 et de £ 100 poor an capital sapérieur à £40,000. Ce n'est donc pas ca faible tarif qui & pa constituer sa capital. Busaite, pour être admis dans la Corporation, le candidat doit veraer € 250, à titre de droit d'entrée ; plus une somme égale sa tantième da capital de la Corporation qui reviendrait à chaque membre en cas de dissolation. Aujourd'hui ce tantième est évalué à 500 livres, ce qui suppose 20,000 livres de capital social. Nous attendons maintenant que la Bourse Egyptionne nous explique comment la Corporation s'y est prise pour amasser 010 fortune d'an demi million de frabos sans spécolor.

Le fait de cette fortune sabite ne pouvait manquer d'attirer l'attention des personnes les plus intéressées à la correction des affaires. Lea Banquiers ne veulent pas dépouiller les Agents de change du droit d'accorder l'admis. sion à la cote ; ils demandent simplement d'être admis en proportion égale avec les courtiers à discuter les admiesions, ce qui n'est pas da tout la même choso.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Caire, 17 janvier. Le taux d'escompts à Londres vient d'être encore élavé de fa 3 $. par suita da resserrement monétaire qui se manifeste à nouveau sur les marchés financiers du continent.
Le Consolidé anglais est renseigné en baigre de 1 à 89 . L'Unifiée a également reculé de à 101. Les autres valeurs égyptiennes sont toutes invariées.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Poncier est restée stationnaire $ 798. La Banque d'Athènes a ga. goé 2 francs à 133.
Ici, le marché des valears a été, comme hier, extrêmement calme. Il y a eu très peu de trapsactions, et on s'est, généralement, tenu aux cours de la veille.

Tont au plus pout-on noter que la National Bank a fait 25 g l'action ancienne et 24 la non velle. L'Immobilière a été cotée à 355; lo Land Allotment à 3 13/16 et 94 I la part de fondateur; l'Agricole da Nil å 246.
Les obligations à lots da Crédit Foncier 6e sont inscrites à 32 : l'ancienne et 274, ache. teurs, la nouvelle.
Les Estates ont été offerta à 19. Les Markets ont clôturé à 23 eh. 3.

Nous apprenons que M. Nangovich boy, l'aimable et sympathique représentant de l'indastrie hôtelière en Egypte, vient d'acheter aux Pyramides, à côté da Mena Honse, on terrain de 160 mètres de façade sur 1.10 de profondeur, c'est-à-dire que superficie totale de plas de 20 000 mètres carrés, au prix de P. E. 40 le mètre, soit en tont £ 8,000. . Cet achat a été fait par le: Nongovich Hotels par le cas où la Cour d'appel confirmerait le jogement ren-In par le 'Tribnyal mixto de 1ère igatance da Caire dans l'affsire en préemption intentée par Rifky pacha. Dans ce caz, la So ciété oréerait, à côté da Mens Hoase, on botel ponporront.
C'est donc ce qu'on pourrait appeler, en quelque sorte, un terrain d'entente... Espérons qu'il n'y aura pas d'autres préempteurs dans le voisinage.
Suivant des informations d'Alexandrie, il serait question de la fusion prochaine de la So. ciété Egyptienne d Batreprises urbaines et ra. rales avec la Building Lands of Egypt.

La Building Land: avait été formée à Ale xandrie, au mois de mai 1901, aq capital de £159,000, raprésenté par 37,500 actions de £4 chacune. Parmi les fondatears figarait l'Beyptiau Investment and Agency (Abdy) avec une Bonacription de 32,000 actions.
L. Société Egyptiende prendre à sa cbargo les affaires de la Buildiog Lands et rembourserait celle ci avec des actions Urbaines.

Ajoutons que d'après des renseignements complémontaires, la Société d'Botreprises or baines et rurales distribuerait, pour son premier exercice de sept mois finissant au 31 décembre dernier, un dividende de P.E 22 sur les actions et un coupon de P.R. 44 pour la part de topdateur.
Le délai fixé aux actionnaires de l'Egyptian Baterprise and Development Co. pour la 8008oription aux actions de la nouvelle émission & été prorogé au 5 février proobain.
Rappelons en même temps que l'assemblée générale ordinaire de cette Société sera tende, au siège social au Caire, samedi prochain 20 janvier, à 4 h. p.m.

Une 5ème répartition d'actif à raison P.R. 5 par action privilégiée de la Banque Industrielle d'Egypto en liquidation est distribuée à partir d'anjoard'hui, sox guichuts do Crédit Lyonnais à A exandrie, contre remise du coupon N° 5.
Les cours de coton sont sigaalés en nog velle hau890 en Amérique. Le disponible a encore gagoé 10 points ; la Mai et l'Octobre 14 et 9 points respectivement
Les arrivages ont été de 35,000 balles contre 21,000.
Le marché de Liverpool ost forme.
Ici, le Mars a ouvert à 16 3,32 pour cloturer à 16 1/16.

On poas cible de Liverpool que d'après des avis autoriséa de New Orleans, la hausse n'est pallement déterminée, comme on l'avait prétenda, par les manæavras de la spéoulation, mais bien par le fait des positions réelles, la quantité totale de coton filable daos la ré colte de l'année 'excédant pas décidément 9,600,000 balles, comme on nous l'annonçait bier.
Sur le désir manifesté par quelques ang de dos lecteard, nous mettons depuis bier en marge de la cote da jour, le montant da nominal et da versé des valeurs qui figurent gar notre tableau des cours.

Nous sagriODS gré à nos lecteurs de nous signaler les omissions qu'ils pourraient re marquer sur ce tableau, ou bien de nous indiquer les améliorations qu'ils voudraient encore voir apporter à notre Circulaire.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

World-wide reputation.
P: Sohnack, Proprietor
Level Wooded Walks.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
